questions.question:
Question 1: A 25-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and dysuria. The 
examination finding is shown below. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image showing strawberry vagina and cervix are suggestive of 
trichomoniasis. The drug of choice is metronidazole. It is given as a single dose of 2g. Both metronidazole and tinidazole are effective in the management of trichomonas vaginitis. 
Tinidazole has been reported to have fewer GI-related side effects and less resistance compared to 
metronidazole. However, it is much more expensive and is preferred in cases refractory to 
metronidazole.

questions.question: Question 2: Metronidazole is selectively active against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms because:

options.a: Aerobes have oxygen gradient inside the cell which deactivates metronidazole moiety
options.b: Only anaerobes and microaerophilic organisms reduce it to generate reactive nitro radicals
options.c: Aerobes have efflux drug pumping mechanism for metronidazole
options.d: Metronidazole inserts pore in the cell membrane of anaerobes and microaerophilic bacteria

questions.explanation:
Metronidazole is selectively active against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms because only 
these organisms reduce it to generate reactive nitro radicals. They contain electron transport components that donate an electron to metronidazole. This 
results in the formation of a highly reactive nitro radical anion that targets DNA and kills the 
organism.

questions.question:
Question 3: 523 
Sold by @itachibot A child presents with diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal pain. His mother reports stools to 
be greasy and foul-smelling. A wet preparation of the stool sample is shown below. What is 
first-line therapy for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the presence of cysts of Giardia lamblia in stool point towards a 
diagnosis of giardiasis, and tinidazole is the treatment of choice for this condition. Both metronidazole and tinidazole are considered first-line drugs however, tinidazole is 
considered superior in its efficacy in comparison to metronidazole. Drug dosage: • Metronidazole: 250- 500mg TID orally for 7 days • Tinidazole: 2g single dose orally The cyst of Giardia is small and oval, and is surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall. Its internal 
structure includes two pairs of nuclei grouped at one end. A young cyst contains one pair of 
nuclei. The axostyle lies diagonally, forming a dividing line within the cyst wall.

questions.question: Question 4: Metronidazole is least likely to be effective in the treatment of:
questions.explanation:
Metronidazole is not effective in the management of pneumocystosis caused by Pneumocystis 
jirovecii. Co-trimoxazole is used in the management of this condition. Metronidazole is used in the following conditions: • Giardiasis • Trichomoniasis • Amoebiasis 535 
Sold by @itachibot • Bacterial vaginosis • Anaerobic infections - bacteroides and clostridium. • Pseudomembranous colitis (alternative to vancomycin & fidaxomicin)

questions.question:
Question 5: A 6-year-old boy presents with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea. The stool examination 
finding is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used for the eradication of 
intestinal cysts in this condition? 524 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows hematophagous trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is not 
an effective agent against cysts of amoeba in the colon. Metronidazole is used in the treatment of amoebiasis (amoebic colitis, amoebic liver abscess). It is 
well absorbed from the small intestine and only a small amount of the unabsorbed drug reaches 
the colon, which is insufficient to kill the cysts. Hence, luminal agents like diloxanide furoate, nitazoxanide or iodoquinol are required for the 
eradication of cysts and trophozoites in the intestine.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is used in the treatment of a patient with asymptomatic intestinal 
amoebiasis?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for the treatment of asymptomatic intestinal luminal amoebiasis due to E. 
histolytica is paromomycin. Paromomycin (aminosidine) is an aminoglycoside that has poor oral absorption and hence it acts 
only in the intestinal lumen as a luminal amebicide. It has no effect against extraintestinal 
organisms.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 21-year-old male presented to the OPD complaining of blood-streaked stools. 
Sigmoidoscopy was done and it showed ulcers in the sigmoid. Biopsy was taken from this 
area and the histopathological image is given below. Which of the following is the most 
appropriate treatment? 525 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are 
suggestive of intestinal amoebiasis. The most appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole. The amoebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. The 
ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the 
ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region. Three classes of drugs are used in the treatment of amebiasis: • Luminal amoebicides- diloxanide furoate, iodoquinol, paromomycin, and tetracycline. They act 
in the intestinal lumen but not in tissues. • Tissue amoebicides- emetine and chloroquine. They are effective in systemic infection but less 
effective in the intestine. • Both luminal and tissue amebicides- Metronidazole, tinidazole and imidazole. They act on both 
sites and are the drug of choice for treating amebic colitis and amebic liver abscess. 536 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient presents with sudden onset fever with chills and malaise. On examination 
splenomegaly was present. Bone marrow picture is shown in the image. Which of the 
following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the bone marrow picture showing macrophages infected with intracellular 
Leishman-Donovan bodies point towards a diagnosis of visceral 
leishmaniasis. Hydroxychloroquine is not indicated in the treatment of this condition. The drugs effective in visceral leishmaniasis are: • Liposomal amphotericin B (preferred) • Sodium stibogluconate (not in India) • Miltefosine • Paromomycin • Pentamidine (rarely used) Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial agent and is also used in the treatment of dermatological 
conditions like: • Cutaneous lupus erythematosus • Cutaneous dermatomyositis • Polymorphous light eruption • Porphyria cutanea tarda • Sarcoidosis

questions.question:
Question 9: A 32-year-old woman presents with the finding as shown in the image. She gives history of 
travel to South America and was bitten by a reduvid bug. Which of the following is the drug of 
choice for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The scenario and the image showing Romaña sign point towards a diagnosis of Chagas disease 
(American trypanosomiasis) and the drug of choice in this condition is benznidazole. American trypanosomiasis is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and can be managed by either 
benznidazole or nifurtimox. Due to its favorable safety profile, benznidazole is considered the 
drug of choice. Romaña sign is the unilateral painless periorbital swelling associated with the acute stage of 
Chagas disease. Albendazole and metronidazole are not indicated for American trypanosomiasis. Albendazole is 
used in infections with Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichiura and hookworms. Metronidazole 
is used in the treatment of trichomoniasis and amebiasis.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient presents in the late stage of West African sleeping sickness. What is the drug of 
choice in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Nifurtimox in combination with eflornithine is the drug of choice for late-stage West African 
sleeping sickness. It is caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense. Nifurtimox alone is indicated in American trypanosomiasis. 537 
Sold by @itachibot Melarsoprol is the drug of choice for late-stage East African (Rhodesian) trypanosomiasis. It is not 
indicated in combination with nifurtimox.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following drugs can be used as first-line treatment in patients with early-stage of 
East African trypanosomiasis?
questions.explanation:
Suramin is the first-line therapy for early-stage East African trypanosomiasis caused by 
Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense. It is also active against Trypanosoma brucei gambiense but only indicated as a second-line agent 
when pentamidine fails or is contraindicated. Melarsoprol is the only effective drug available for the treatment of the late encephalopathic stage 
of East African sleeping sickness. It is caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense. Melarsoprol is 
effective in earlier stages also but is avoided because of its toxicity.

questions.question:
Question 12: The microscopy of fecal sample of a patient showed presence of Ascaris lumbricoides eggs. 
This condition can most effectively be treated with which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Roundworm infestation is most effectively treated with albendazole. It is considered as the drug of 
choice for the treatment of roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides) infestation. Albendazole is considered as the drug of choice for treatment of infestation by: • Whipworm - Trichuris trichura causing trichuriasis • Hookworm - Ancylostoma duodenale • Roundworm - Ascaris lumbricoides • Dog tapeworm - Echinococcus granulosus causing hydatid disease Albendazole is administered as a single oral 400-mg dose to adults and children more than 2 
years of age. Safety is not established for children less than 2 years. However, according to WHO, 
if the benefit outweighs the risk, albendazole at 200 mg can be given to children between the ages 
of 1-2years.

questions.question: Question 13: What is the primary mechanism of action of benzimidazole?
questions.explanation:
The primary mechanism of action of benzimidazoles is by inhibition of microtubule 
polymerization. Benzimidazoles bind to beta-tubulin and cause inhibition of microtubule 
polymerization. Drugs belonging to the benzimidazole group are: • Albendazole • Mebendazole • Triclabendazole • Thiabendazole. 538 
Sold by @itachibot Mechanisms of action: • Inhibition of mitochondrial fumarate reductase • Reduced glucose transport • Uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation

questions.question:
Question 14: A young man working at a dairy farm presents with fever and abdominal pain. Examination 
of his stool samples revealed the finding shown in the image. Which of the following 
benzimidazoles is indicated in this condition? 528 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image showing operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) is suggestive 
of Fasciola hepatica and the benzimidazole indicated for infection with this organism is 
triclabendazole.

questions.question:
Question 15: The MRI of a patient who presented with new-onset seizures is shown below. What is the 
drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
The MRI findings (multiple cysticerci within the brain) are suggestive of neurocysticercosis and 
albendazole is the drug of choice in this condition. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole and continued for several 
days after the commencement of therapy. It reduces the inflammatory reaction to the dead and 
dying cysticerci of Taenia solium. Note: Even though Albendazole and Praziquantel are used as a combination, the single best 
answer choice to this question is Albendazole.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 25-year-old man hospitalized with a hydatid cyst refused to undergo surgical removal of the 
cyst. He was treated with high dose albendazole for 3 months. This patient should be 
monitored for toxicity to the:
questions.explanation:
The patient described above should be monitored for toxicity to the liver. Liver dysfunction is one 
of the common adverse effects of albendazole therapy and liver function tests should be routinely 
conducted when long-term therapy is initiated. Long-term albendazole therapy is also associated with bone marrow toxicity. Therefore, blood 
counts should also be regularly monitored.

questions.question: Question 17: What is the drug of choice in patients with onchocerciasis?
questions.explanation:
Ivermectin is the drug of choice for onchocerciasis caused by Oncocerca volvulus in adults and 
children aged more than 5 years. Ivermectin is the drug of choice for: • Strongyloidiasis • Onchocerciasis 539 
Sold by @itachibot It is associated with Mazzotti reaction (fever, pruritic rash, lymphadenopathy) as a side 
effect when given for filariasis due to immune system activation by the dying parasite. This 
reaction is also seen with the use of diethylcarbamazine.

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient presents with itchy, serpiginous eruptions as shown in the image. He says that these 
lesions advance rapidly to different sites. What is the primary mechanism of action of the 
drug preferred for this disease? 530 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Activation of glutamate gated chloride channels
options.b: Inhibition of glutamate gated chloride channels

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the image showing larva currens, points towards a diagnosis of 
strongyloidiasis, and the drug of choice in this condition is ivermectin. The mechanism of action 
of ivermectin primarily involves activation of glutamate-gated chloride channels found only in 
invertebrates. Ivermectin activates glutamate-activated chloride channels in the nerves and muscles of nematode 
and results in the influx of chloride into the cell. This causes hyperpolarization of cells and results 
in paralysis of nematodes.

questions.question: Question 19: What is the first-line treatment for a patient presenting with the finding shown below?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Ivermectin is the first-line drug for the 
treatment of cutaneous larva migrans. The first-line drugs used in cutaneous larva migrans include: • Ivermectin - 200g/kg orally single dose • Albendazole - 400mg orally for 3 days

questions.question:
Question 20: A 17-year-old boy presents with painless hematuria. He has a history of travel to Kenya. Urine 
microscopy revealed the finding shown below. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the image showing the egg of Schistosoma hematobium (egg with 
terminal spine), point towards the diagnosis of schistosomiasis. Praziquantel is the drug of choice 
for schistosomiasis caused by all Schistosoma species that can infect humans. A single oral dose of 40 mg/kg or three doses of 20 mg/kg each, given 4–6 h apart, generally 
produce cure rates of 70%–95% and consistently high reductions (>85%) in egg counts.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following drugs causes flaccid paralysis of Ascaris lumbricoides?
questions.explanation:
Piperazine causes flaccid paralysis of Ascaris lumbricoides. It acts as a GABA receptor agonist and increases chloride ion conductance across the Ascaris 
muscle membrane. This results in hyperpolarisation and reduced excitability, which leads to 
muscle relaxation and flaccid paralysis. Metrifonate, levamisole and tribendimidine are anthelminthic drugs that cause spastic paralysis. 540 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: 532 
Sold by @itachibot Diethylcarbamazine is used for the treatment of:
questions.explanation:
Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is used for the control and treatment of lymphatic filariasis caused by 
W. bancrofti, B. malayi and B. timori. Other indications for the use of DEC are: • Loiasis • Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

questions.question:
Question 23: A patient presents with fever, fatigue, and malaise. Investigations reveal anemia and 
thrombocytopenia. Thin blood smear is shown below. What is the recommended therapy for 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the microscopic image showing tetrads or Maltese cross, point towards a 
diagnosis of babesiosis and the recommended therapy for this condition is azithromycin plus 
atovaquone. Babesiosis is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria. It presents with febrile illness, hemolysis 
and hemoglobinuria. For mild or moderate disease: Azithromycin plus atovaquone. For severe disease: • Recommended regimen - azithromycin plus atovaquone. • Alternative regimen - clindamycin plus quinine. Severe babesiosis typically occurs in patients with one or more of the following characteristics: age 
>50 years, neonatal prematurity, asplenia/hyposplenism, HIV/AIDS, malignancy, and 
immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.question:
Question 24: A patient presented with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed IgM 
toxoplasma antibodies. Which of the following agents is most effective in treating this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Pyrimethamine is the most effective agent against toxoplasmosis and is present in most of the 
regimens. It is combined with sulfadiazine or clindamycin for toxoplasmosis. Trimethoprim plus sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) is an alternative. 541 
Sold by @itachibot Antifungal Agents
